reviewText:
Ok, I feel I have to step up and deliver my first and probably only review as I feel so strongly that people have really not given this game the chance it rightly deserves.

The Gods will be watching really brought back the nostalgic feeling of the old point and click style adventures some of you may remember from the early 90's, for me the music and graphics really sell the game. They are meant to be retro, this is good people!! the backing tracks are epic and will have you turn up the sound as you play this difficult (but by no means dark souls esque) as you try and try to save everyone and then decend into just trying to complete your objective at all costs.

You play Sergeant Burden a man who is resolute in his beliefs and weary of them at the same time. Undercover for months inflitrating a terrorist organisation that is trying to free people from galactic slavery.
As the story progresses the lines of morality are blurred until you are not sure who is right, or why it matters at all.

So for the gameplay, each scenario is pretty much stand alone but links the story together. In each there is an overarching objective to accomplish but with harsh contraints that mean you can't have your cake and eat it. Things will go wrong and its about learning what works and what doesn't (though there are multiple solutions). You have to manage the people under you and try (or not try) to get them out alive.

Once you learn that the game is not going to give you the win on a plate it makes it easier decide to take crazy actions from the start , that help you in the end!. It makes  for good play with a partner deciding what to do next, and dealing with the frustrations together.

There is about 6 chapters to get through, so it could be short if you are really good but the experience is worth it and hope these developers get more credit for a unique and stellar game experience.

reviewText:
I'm not really sure what this game was trying to do.

It's not really a narrative where your actions matter, as the plot chugs forward no matter what you do so long as you survive the current chapter.

So, it's not really about tough decisions and consequences.

It's not really about gameplay, either, since everything you do has randomly generated effects on if you win or fail a current chapter, and little to no information about the outcome of your decisions is given to the player except for failure.

This is fitting, since this means the game itself fails as a narrative AND an interactive experience, while marketing itself as an interesting combination of the two.

It really just boils down to randomly barking orders to get the rather mediocre tech scifi political plot to trudge forward.

You'd get the same experience from reading a mediocre scifi novel and flipping a coin to see if you could turn a page.  Heads, you progress.  Tails, read the book from the beginning.  If that sounds tedious to you, then it'd be best to stay away from this game.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There has been a lot of flak received on this game, but for those of you who are interested, yes this is a point and click game, and yes you will fail alot at what seems to be an unfair system.

you actually have to figure out the mechanics of each scene to succeed, you have to notice patterns and work with said patterns.

The game is beautiful and ive personally payed for the collectors edition, which to me, the soundtrack alone was worth the extra 10$ but it also came with an awesome artbook and a nice little prologue comic of decent length ( in regards to the length of the game)

the real beauty of this game is how everything ties into the story, and how everything comes together in the end. its worth perservering and the game is indeed possible. ( ive finished it in original mode )

People just cant seem to appreciate the intricacy of the story, and how well its played out with the minimalist medium, using your imagination to conjure up just how horrible the scenarios are in this game. i cant praise it enough, and i can see that its either love it or hate it, but i encourage anyone who enjoys a good story and has a single iota of patience and love for cryptic puzzle-like gameplay, to buy this game.

this game has hit a home run for me, and its up among my favorites,

reviewText: Overall, I think this is a brilliant game so far. Having to choose the life or death of a character to save the team, or having to sacrafice another person's life to save your own really makes for a game about moral decisions. At some points I felt the need to quit the game because I knew that if I ran out of firewood and food at the same time, or failed to fulfill my duty, someone would be killed, or die. Although this is a good game with plenty of decisions that will bear weight on you in the end, this game has many scenarios where there isn't really a right or correct answer, leaving a character dead or injured, this can be frustrating at times.\n\nOverall, if you want a point and click game that isn't so much about puzzles, but decision making, this is one of those games.

reviewText:
This game has what looks like a neat story, but two really major problems.

Narratively, the lack of choice is not only annoying in and of itself, but extremely poorly-executed. This becomes evident early on in the game where, as an example, a character has a chance of dying, but if they do, they show up again in the next chapter like nothing happened at all. The game literally retcons a character's death. There is an explanation given later on (timelines, Groundhog Day), but it feels lazy and unsatisfying.

The other problem is that it's deliberately difficult in a way that isn't fun. Unless you're on narrative mode, if you get through any scene on the first try, it's by sheer luck. Randomness has a high chance of wrecking you, and even with minimal random elements, most of the puzzles require a few deaths and restarts before you have a handle on how things work.

The game has a deliberate theme of helplessness and futility that carries over to the mechanics, which seems intentional. As a concept it's interesting, but let's make a game that's unpleasant to play" is a self-defeating thing that exists only for the artistic statement. And I cannot recommend you spend money on that."

reviewText: This game is composed of time sensitive, micro-managing with two opposing forces battling it out. It was difficult to complete and impossible to win without dying...a lot. Overall I highly recommend it because, above else, it was fun to play. The game was clever and challenging while still holding a story line. It was also dark and left you with a tough decision.

reviewText: Alright, first of all: I get why some people don't like this game, it is significantly different from traditional point-and-click-adventures and it is on the edge between harsh challenge and frustration. However, if you like trial-and-error approaches as in dark souls and super meat boy and also strategic, turn-based thinking, I would highly recommend picking this one up.\n\nPersonally I also enjoyed the story (sci-fi, breaking the wall... but certainly one of the better ones) and the visual presentation, which sometimes imho seems very immersive, even gory which is really impressive given that you can basically count the pixels.

reviewText:
By far the best game I've ever played. This game melted my brain, and with the addition of the DLC, sucked all of the brain juice up and spat it in my face. Not sure whether that's a good thing or a bad thing, but I love it.

After thinking about this game for a long time: DON'T buy this game if you are looking for a traditionally fun game. DON'T buy this game if you only look at the gameplay elements, because I will admit, they are a bit repetitive. DON'T buy this game if you are not prepared to be challenged, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, and occasionally ragequit and restart on an easier setting. DO buy this game if you can understand, appreciate, and love a depressing story of a man who just can't catch a break.

Best game in my library, and I have Undertale, Thomas was Alone, The Stanley Parable, and The Beginner's Guide in my library.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that I've only just now completed this game on Easy and I'm working on the Original mode right now. I have not seen everything that the game has to offer. This is sort of a 'first impressions' review. If I have to alter the review or write a new one in the future, I will, but I'm pretty sure this covers most of what's going on.

This is a trial-and-error game. A 'ooh, what does this button do' kind of game. It's a learning process, and if you beat then entire game on the first try of your first time loading it, then you've just been insanely lucky and there's all that is to it. If you don't like repeating processes to improve your game, then you're not going to like this game at all.

I didn't find this game difficult. I didn't get anything correct on the first try, and I was stuck in that damn desert for hours, but nothing seemed difficult to me. And when Original is labeled as difficult, I expected Easy to be... About as hard as it was for me. If you jumped in on Original without understanding how things worked, then you're not gonna have a good time, but you should be able to pick up what's going on very quickly.

When the game was harsh and unforgiving, it felt like it was supposed to be harsh and unforgiving. I found myself speed-clicking through repeating cutscenes after losing a level(?) but that was the only time I ever felt annoyed with it, and I barely even felt it, then.

The graphics and animation are pretty solid. I mention below that a few things looked buggy for me, but I'm going to look for these things the next time I play to see if it's a problem or just something that happens (or is supposed to happen)? But overall things are really, really good. The sound and effects are well-placed, a little loud in some places, but 99% of the time they hit the nail on the head.

Now, this is where we enter spoiler territory.

Seriously, spoilers from here on out.

One of the problems I had with it was how abrupt the ending felt. It felt like I was just understanding what was going on, and then it was over without explaining it. We learn that Burden's experienced this world/timeline over and over (saves and reloads), but we never really learn why. It just is. The very ending, past the credits, might suggest to a wormhole or a rip in time, but we're kind of left hanging (probably to make room for a sequel), and there's this weird void of 'I don't get it' that lingers.

I can understand why people would think the story and characters are stale. Me, personally, I like the idea of a team doing what it needs to do, and even though the characters were a little generic, that's not a bad thing. All of their roles were made clear and you understood what needed to be done.

The characters of Xenolifer were... Eh. I understand that they were background, but at the very last scene, I had no idea who the people I was holding hostage were or why I should care. And I did my damndest to read and retain the information, but if I shot Claire's son... I mean, aside from it raising and lowering certain stats, I didn't have any reason for not doing it. I didn't have a reason for caring about these people other than the game telling me that I should.

I guess what I'm saying is that we didn't get a whole lot of Burden's background with that organization, and I kinda wanted it. The game has it's limitations, but I would have much rather preferred feeling for characters out of my own volition rather than the game telling me that I should care about them.

Those are really the only problems I have with the game, and they're minor. Some places seemed a little glitchy with the graphics, but I'm going to be playing it through again to see if it's a persisting problem or just a random one.

All in all, it's a good game, and in my opinion it was worth the time and money (I bought it on sale, but it's definitely worth the $10).

If I had to give it a grade:

Graphics: A
Story: B
Characters: B
Actual Gameplay: A

Tl;dr ... Good game dun good.

reviewText:
This game's description is very misleading. It is simply a puzzle, where you must determine the order of things through trial and error. There is no adventure of any kind outside of watching characters move back and forth and reading their words.

A point and click allows for the player to point and click in the order in which makes the most sense to them. This title doesn't even allow that, so it isn't truly a point and click game either. It is simple a puzzle game with no instructions desguised as something it is very much not.

I imagine that for a puzzle it would be considered a good game. However I am not a fan of puzzle games. At least not anything like this. I would certainly not recomend this as an indie adventure game or an indie point & click game. Simply because it is neither.

Total bait and switch...

reviewText:
Tldr; Story is bad, if you like luck based management resource games then you'll like this.  Game is pretty.

I will preface this by saying that I don't enjoy luck based games, especially those that punish the player almost purely on luck.  I do enjoy narrative games though, and for that reason I have played this game on narrative mode.

I enjoy this game conceptually.  The themes of circular time, heavy social issues, and tough survival elements makes this game interesting.  However, I don't think the game came through on many of its ideas and in general, could use a lot of work.

The narrative is awful.  I played through the entire story including the epilogue so that I might understand the story more thoroughly. All of the characters had the same type of speech, and all in all it felt like every character was the same person, which is a sign of poor writing.  The writing was superfluous and flowery with no real meaning behind the words.  The emphasis on depth and the urgency of the each scenario wasn't reflected in the writing.

The main character has points where he just jumps into these auto-fellatious monologues which is to say,  I didn't enjoy at all. I felt the overall philosophical message the writer was trying to communicate was flawed. Unfortunately,  the writing projects depth, but is unable to deliver. I didn't care for Burden, or the biblical and pseudo victorian-esque naming of his character.

The narrative then in turn suffers from the main game mechanics in which there are several scenarios where you depend on luck and management of resources in a survival situation.  If this is your type of thing, then go for it; I did not enjoy this.  Even if this is a game mechanic is intended by the developers as what they were aiming for, it doesn't make it a good mechanic.  The high failure rate coupled with the fact the survival portions of the games need so much time to complete is awful.  This is most prominent in chapter 3.  I played it on narrative mode, so I didn't have to restart as many times however, it quickly became frustrating and that frustration takes away from the narrative in a way that I became more focused on completing the objective than the characters who can easily die.  This is tedious, and I understand they were probably going for a Dark Souls thing (I liked Dark Souls a lot), but the mechanics come off as cumbersome and don't encourage exploration or different tactics as the choice of tactics are limited anyway.

Further, it doesn't actually matter if the characters die because of spoilers. Again, there is a narrative reason for this but I felt that it cheapened the story.

I will say that the visuals are beautiful. I enjoyed the aesthetic of the game immensely. I particularly liked the desert scenery and thought the navigation portion of the game was one of the strongest parts gameplay wise. The music was not memorable, which is unfortunate.

reviewText:
Gameplay is shallow and repetitive. Nice presentation can't salvage it.

Each level consists of a rather shallow 'puzzle.' Usually this is some combination of managing 'risk' and 'reward' bars: Choose research to increase your success level, but it also increases your fatigue! Drink coffee to lower your fatigue but it increases your caffeine! And then add like 3-10 of those on top and there's your 'game.' Hiding the levels doesn't make this fun or interesting (his 'fatigue' meter isn't visible, but you can see him start to pant heavily, for example).

The systems are contrived enough that the game will spend a lot of time explaining your different options every level. But it's not usually enough for you to actually know what the limits are (is he a little tired or is he going to die next turn?) so you'll still have to do it all multiple times, trial & error style. Random events don't help things.

You can turn off random events to prevent unfair deaths, and you can play on 'light' mode to decrease the amount of trial & error you'll need to do, but even then you're left with a basic, slow-paced game that makes you pick the same options over and over again to progress.

reviewText:
Most good games start out by teaching you the mechanics of the game, and easing you into it in the beginning, to prepare you for all the challenges to come.

This game does not do that. It drops you into a scenario and makes no attempt at all to explain to you what sort of game you are playing, or how you're supposed to play it.

The game seems to revel in gleeful delight at how difficult it's going to be, before you start. Pre-emting an excuse for lazy and poor game design does not mitigate its effects.

It's a shame, because this game looks like it might be interesting. If only it wasn't so tedious.

reviewText:
Wow, interesting game.  If you've watched the trailer for the game you're probably thinking that the game is story-driven and has a lot of tough moral choices.  In reality that is very, very far from what the game is.  I believe a lot of the negative reviews end here; the game, simply put, is not what is advertised at all on the Steam page.  I can't really hold it against these reviews since I will agree it is very misleading.

What the game actually consists of are tense, puzzling and incredibly difficult crisis situations where you need to plan your every move carefully.  One mistake can ruin all of your progress and since there are no checkpoints, you'll be right back at the beginning.  It's basically a point and click and you're spending all of your time clicking through menus to find the choice you want.  But while the gameplay isn't exactly thrilling, it does a very good job of making an impact while you're playing it.  It's a very graphic and brutal game despite being pixel art.

Aside from the marketing, the next biggest complaint you'll see is that the game is difficult and arguably unfairly so.  It's true; the game is incredibly difficult, luck can ruin a chapter through no fault of your own and you will die many, many, many times.  That being said, you slowly figure out what the best decisions are and how to deal with certain situations.  It's difficult, it's unfair, but it's not impossible and frankly I think the difficulty level contributes a lot to the atmosphere and tension of the game.

Overall I recommend it pretty highly.  It's a point and click adventure with an impressively dark, gritty and brutal atmosphere that will leave you feeling bad about your choices.

reviewText: I give this game a cautious thumbs up! It's definitely not for everybody but it's a unique game with a high level of challenge. Just don't go in expecting it to be something it's not. If a chapter gets too frustrating it is always possible to play through on an easier difficulty. Lastly, I found the art and sound design to be quite excellent and a pleasure to experience. I would say buy it on sale.

reviewText:
Gods Will Be Watching got me excited ever since I played the original Ludum Dare entry. The artstyle, story, and concept seemed fantastic. The gameplay of the original was simplistic but thought out. However, with the game out and me having played it, I think I was expecting something a bit different than what I got.

The gameplay, at it's core, is resource and time management. In many of the 7 scenarios you will be given a time limit and you will be given a goal to acheive within that limit. You will need to make sure certain things happen. When things start to go bad they will go absolutely ♥♥♥♥ up.  Trial and error will inevitably happen. Hell, the final fight is one long trial and error sequence. You will die and replay the same scenario, skipping the same dialogue over and over. It'll feel more like dark souls than a puzzle game with all the death occuring both to you and around you.

Other reviewers hate the fact that the game is too hard, but don't want to turn it down to easy for some reason. It's a bit like FTL, in which Easy is considered a regular difficulty and Normal is considered a harder difficulty. In the Original difficulty, you are forced to survive by the skin of your teeth, making sacrifices and probably regretting what you've done That's what the game is supposed to make you feel. Dread and despair.

I feel like everyone, including myself, went into this game hoping it would be more of a narrative experience, something akin to The Wolf Among Us. However, this was just not the case, and people got too hyped. Choices don't have much impact at all in the whole scheme of things, and the game is too short to even really be able to reflect any previous decisions, at least not for very long.

I love this game's artstyle, music, plot, characters, and dialogue, and I like the universe it takes place in. But when it comes to actually playing the game, it's just a series of puzzle-like scenarios that need solving. And even then, less puzzle solving and more time and resource management.

TL;DR the game is hard but thats not the issue. The repetition and trial-and-error gameplay drag it down. The concept and artstyle is excellent, but people seemed like they wanted a Telltale game-like narrative experience and instead got a game with 7 different puzzle scenarios in which you are forced to make difficult, soul crushing choices. I would not recommend it if you're quick to frustrate or if you're the kind of person that plays a game trying to get the best possible outcome storywise.

reviewText:
This game isn't bad, by any stretch, but it isn't fun either ... in either a narrative or mechanistic fashion.  To the former, the things it tackles, like slavery, holding hostages, torture, are not easy ones, particularly when you're sometimes on the giving end of them, so it's not a light hearted romp.

But it's the mechanics that kills it.  While it doesn't always have numerical feedback as to how things are progressing (like what level of calmness / rebellion your hostages are at) which is something I actually appreciate ... it's sometimes unclear as to what particular 'gestures' mean.  Are they really anxious or just following orders?  The game lampshades this in the final act, showing that you have to go over and over and over again to understand HOW to play the game ... which isn't a bad thing in and of itself.

What IS bad is that it not only requires you to go through some sections again and again without skipping, some of the things just take FOREVER to accomplish ... the transitions could be snappier and the 'start from the beginning of the chapter' is unforgiving.  Further, even if you're just there for the narrative, the game doesn't give it out sequentially, but instead sometimes semi-randomly, so the point they're making varies ... and if you don't want to miss it, you have to read it all, which is sad because it gets repetitive as you have to restart over and over again to find the patterns to win.

If you can get this free or very cheap, it's an interesting few hours, but be prepared for some painful mechanics.

reviewText:
9/10
The soundtrack was amazingly composed
The brutally difficult gameplay always made me wanna come back and beat the levels individually, then go back and take on some of the challenges (hopefully I will be able to complete more later)
The story itself is interesting, and where it may feel a bit confusing or uninteresting at points, it makes up for it with the game making you feel something with the story segments thrown in the gameplay (and by the very end I was incredibly pleased with how they tied the gameplay into the story, kind of like Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward). The characters were interesting and I genuinely was doing my best to save them all (even Abraham even though after a while that seemed impossible).
The art style is minimalistic with pixels, and yet somehow it still has a lot of impact. I was impressed at how some character deaths albeit being very pixelated were incredibly brutal (just goes to show you what a good developer can do with good graphical design)
Overall I would recommend this to a friend or anyone who really enjoys the point and click genre with a difficult twist reminiscent of Hotline Miami.
It was a very enjoyable experience and I look forward to more of the developer's games in the future.


(Note:
Even though you can enjoy the story on easy difficulty, I find that the story segments seem a lot more rewarding and the overall experience more satisfying on classic difficulty. Don't pan the game on it's difficulty being too hard for you, it's designed for trial and error. Like most things, the more you work at it the better you get.)

reviewText:
So a lot of people have been giving this game some negative reviews for various reasons ranging from `Too hard` to `Bad story` to `Nothing you do matters` etc. Most of these reviews are in my opinion just people complaining without having enough information so how about this; I will go through the Most Useful complaints and most common complaints and comment on them.

`The game is not focused on story/Has a bad story`
This I can say is probably being said by those who aren`t really into reading dialogue. Not trying to insult them and I am sure there are many exceptions, but as someone who has completed the game I can safely say that the story is very very good, not going to spoil it though.

`Game is unfairly diffcult/ No checkpoints/ Unfair RNG`
The game is hard, very hard. It involves a lot of thinking through your moves and planning ahead. One slip up could cost you the round. I wouldn`t however call it unfair. Every failure is your own fault, YOU took an unneccesary risk, YOU didn`t prioritize, even with the presence of an RNG everything is your fault. The game lays out all the mechanics of the puzzle from the beginning and if you pay attention you will know exactly how things work from the moment the puzzle starts. You will probably miss something admittedly, your (probably) human, and there are some things you will just have to test to confirm your suspicions on a mechanic. Concerning the RNG you will probably be fine as long as you don`t try your luck to much. 60% is a magical number separating success and failure in my experience. Having played numerous X-Com originals and remakes I can say that the RNG is fair enough. No checkpoints? Play one of the puzzles and you will realise how much that would break the game. It removes all suspense and worry about your choices.

Well this review is getting a bit long I will try and wrap it up quickly.

`Choice doesn`t matter/Dead characters magically reappear`
Every choice you make influences something. Though as in every game with choice there are only so many ways it can end seeing someone die then come back is, creepy. You may say Well that is dumb that someone who dies comes back
date: that mean there are no concequences!" I can understand that on the surface this seems dumb and when I heard this for the first time I was concerned on the quality of game if it did this. Then my team was decimated on chapter 4. Only a few of us survived
recommended:
then I saw them at the briefing at the beginning of the next chapter and they were... warped. Quote from the main character "Why do I feel like they already died. I need a vacation" Things start to make more sense as to why people die but `live` as you go on.


So I think that is a good place to stop concerning what I thought were some of the most supported damning ideas about this game. I would so much call this a review as a mass response to real reviews. I think this game is awesome though I can understand it not being for everyone
hoursPlayed: I suggest looking at someone playing Chapter One to get a feel for what the game really is before putting money down. Chapter One doesn`t have a TON of story so it shouldn`t spoil much. Northern Lion`s first episode on this game represents it well and he fails so it won`t tell you how to complete the puzzle. I reccomend starting there unless you know of someone else to watch.\n\nQuestions? Concerns? Complaints about this not actually being a review and me being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ blind fanboy? Comment on it. I am new to presenting ideas like this or reviewing in general so I could use the feedback."

reviewText:
I don't know why there's so much hate over this game. Yeah, it's hard as ♥♥♥♥, but so were the classic point and clicks from back in the day. This game is just more grim and in your face about it.

The whole point of the game is to fail, learn from your failure, and then start again. eventually, you figure it out and move forward. The story is compelling, the pixel art is great, and even though there's a tonne of point and clicks out there, this seems to have a unique feel.

I actually played the game through and really liked it. Sure, there were a few times where I was cursing at my monitor and had to walk away. But the game drew me back in because I had to see the end of the story.

This game certainly isn't for everyone, but I sure as hell liked it.

reviewText:
Gods Will Be Watching has a great storyline, and awesome gameplay, that almost anyone can enjoy.

Pros:
Point and click
Moral Decisions (this game will make yourself feel like a horrible person)
Challenge (took me 15-16 hours to beat on original)
feels longer than it is
All over great design
Decent ending

Cons:
A glitch or two here and there
Only Seven Levels (they feel longer though)
Tedious mouse clicking (speech)
The save system (saves at the beginning of a mission instead of the middle or near end)
Some Game crashes here and there.

Overall, this game was a lot of fun though. it was a challenge to go through every level, each one usualy harder than the last, and a good storyline never hurts too. the ending (either one you choose) leaves the game open to a sequel, so hopefully we get one soon!
9/10

reviewText:
This game is amazing. The two things that really shine about this game to me are gameplay and the story, and are the main things I'll go over. I'll go into depth on these and any other subjects of the review in separate sections so you can look at what you're interested in. (warning- the words level and chapter are interchangeable)

Quick review of Collector's Edition- The Collector's Edition adds no content to the game, but rather, gives you a wealth of non-game content- with the amazing soundtrack, a prequel comic focused on Liam and Shaman, and an artbook that has some great tidbits of information scattered throughout it, it's definitely worth the extra cash. #yourewelcomedevs

Gameplay- This game is a one-of-a-kind game. I think of it as a new sub-genre of point and click games- a 'dynamic point and click resource management/ emotional thriller' type-thing. Crap, it's hard to explain this game. First off, this game is a seriously challenging game. You have to take into account all of the factors of each level and plan and manage accordingly. It's a unique experience that tests your mettle in many ways- it tests your adaptability, planning, attentiveness, presents lots of ethical and moral dilemmas, too. This game might not be for the faint of heart, not only because it is mentally and occasionally emotionally challenging, but it also has some surprisingly graphical and gory deaths that I had no idea could be done with pixel art (0.o). Seriously, this game can mess with your mind if you get too invested into it- for those who enjoy that, like me, go ahead, but if you aren't into that, treat with caution (or meds).

Story- This game has a seriously beautiful and detailed story and lore. Although you don't dig too deep into the story or lore in the first few levels, they grow exponentially throughout the later levels, and in the last 2 levels and the new final chapter, it connects so many of the dots the game left lying around that it left me breathless. I really don't want to spoil the story for you, as the story really is a huge part of the game and what got me hooked, but keep in mind while you play the game that you're eventually going to see the whole picture. If you think you're prone to stress or boredom from suspense like that, you might not enjoy the game, but if you're patient about the revelations of the story then you'll be rewarded by those in the final few chapters. The Collector's Edition will help add to your understanding of the story.

I bid you farewell with one more comment- since this game is about puzzle solving and story following, it won't have a lot of replay value (unless you're a serious completionist).

reviewText:
I loved this game. I loved everything about it. I have only beaten it on the easiest setting, but I plan to go back and find out exactly how difficult the other settings are, but this game was awesome. If you're thinking about buying this game, let me highlight my favorite things about this masterpiece:

- The music and sound is superb, nothing was jarring or so out-of-the-ordinary that it pulled me out of the game, the music was thrilling when necessary and quiet when the situation demanded it.
- The story, my god, this game has an awesome story, with so many layers to it that I was just more and more intrigued the further I went into it. It is dark science fiction, with such realistic and human ideals warring beside one another that you'll want to finish it just to learn more about the characters and to find out the ending.
- The puzzles are what make this game, they're diverse, challenging and story-driven. A lot of them have random variables thrown in, so when you lose, you can't rely upon your prior knowledge. It is so thrilling to finally beat a segment of the game, you really feel accomplished.

I picked this up when it was on sale, the only thing that left me disappointed was the fact that the game wasn't longer.

reviewText: I read it somewhere and I completely agree: at the highest difficulty level Gods Will Be Watching is the Dark Souls of the adventure genre. Hard, frustrating, punishing, never tells you what you're doing wrong to fail the mission. And I like it for that, nowadays games always provide the exact explanation about what you have to do, reminders, hints and so on, as if the players were stupids or childs.\n\nI wouldn't call it a point and click adventure game though, at least not a classic one. It's more of a puzzle game, with a very compelling narrative aspect (you'll face very delicate moral decisions) and gorgeous pixel art. So, if you're looking for a proper point and click adventure maybe this is not the game you're looking for, but if you're up for really challenging puzzles (not complex puzzles, but situation in which you have to control a very large number of different factors and keep all of them in balance if you want to succeed) and moral dilemmas, well, I can assure you you'll end up angry, but you'll probably love it. Thumbs up.

reviewText:
I loved this game. I loved everything about it. I have only beaten it on the easiest setting, but I plan to go back and find out exactly how difficult the other settings are, but this game was awesome. If you're thinking about buying this game, let me highlight my favorite things about this masterpiece:

- The music and sound is superb, nothing was jarring or so out-of-the-ordinary that it pulled me out of the game, the music was thrilling when necessary and quiet when the situation demanded it.
- The story, my god, this game has an awesome story, with so many layers to it that I was just more and more intrigued the further I went into it. It is dark science fiction, with such realistic and human ideals warring beside one another that you'll want to finish it just to learn more about the characters and to find out the ending.
- The puzzles are what make this game, they're diverse, challenging and story-driven. A lot of them have random variables thrown in, so when you lose, you can't rely upon your prior knowledge. It is so thrilling to finally beat a segment of the game, you really feel accomplished.

I picked this up when it was on sale, the only thing that left me disappointed was the fact that the game wasn't longer.

reviewText:
Unbelievably tedious and boring.

I have to admit, the atmosphere of this game is spot on. It does a good job of making you feel like you're under pressure and like every choice matters.

Unfortunately, that wears off after the first playthrough.

In Gods Will Be Watching, you're put into all kinds of bad situations, such as a hostage situation where you'll have to control all of the hostages and hack into a system to steal information while keeping the authorities at bay. You get all kinds of moral dilemmas, like your crewmembers breaking down mid-mission, forcing you to try and stabilize them emotionally, to hostages becoming panicked and making a suicidal dash for the door.

The only problem is the game's difficulty and repetitiveness. The game prides itself on being unforgivable and difficult, but that's really the biggest flaw. Every time you fail, you'll have to start over from the very beginning, even if that reverts 10 minutes of progress. Every single time you die, you'll be forced to play the same part again, which will take another 5 or 10 minutes.

You've already gone through this situation before, though. The emotion and tension has worn off, so now it's just you clicking buttons and hoping that the game looks favorably upon you. And if you press the wrong button? Why, say goodbye to the last 10 minutes of progress you made.

Seriously, this game has an interesting atmosphere and story already, but I couldn't be bothered to finish it. Even on the easiest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ difficulty, it's just so mind-numbingly boring. I'd like to experience the story, but I'm hardly gonna pay attention to it when I'm bored out of my mind.

In summary: Gameplay is solid enough, atmosphere is pretty good. Lack of saves and extreme difficulty lead to extremely tedious repetitiveness, which makes the game pretty much unbearable for me.

I wanted to like this game, but no. Definitely not recommend.

Oh, yeah. I should also add that the game runs like absolute ♥♥♥♥. It somehow uses more RAM than next-gen triple A games. I find that the framerate dropped constantly and there was a load of stuttering, even though it's just a little bit of pixel art. And then alt-tabbing. It took me about five minutes to recover after I alt-tabbed from this game and put my PC to sleep. Not well optimized at all.

reviewText: A little bit puzzle game, a little bit resource management, and hugely infuriating and often utterly, unfairly difficult. But it's still great. My main problem with the game up to this point was that a lot of the events during the scenarios had very harsh stochastic elements -- so basically, no matter how well you had learned to beat the scenarios (through painful trial and error) you could be totally screwed over by the roll of a dice. This kind of thing can be OK occasionally, and add an element of risk to the game, but I reckon it was turned up way too high in the earlier versions. The latest patch includes a mode that removes a lot of the stochastic elements, which I think makes the game a lot better, but without lowering the difficulty TOO much. So, yeah, no worries there any more. Other than that, it's a pretty neat little game that looks fantastic and is set in a cool sci-fi universe. I think people will either love this or hate it -- no middle ground -- because the gameplay is pretty niche. There are a few other issues here and there (why do characters that died keep coming back to life??) But I really enjoyed it, even though the gameplay can be very tough, I still kept coming back.

reviewText: To start: I used to add a longer header to these reviews describing my scoring ethos, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page. Also, I first wrote a review for this game before The Mercy Update
date:
so I'll mainly be talking in reference to this update.

Gameplay: Skip Original and go to Puzzle. Trust me; you'll have a better time. Original is difficult but laden with RNG, Puzzle is difficult but predictable. In fact, I never even beat Chapter 1 on Original mode due to how crazy the RNG could get for me at times. Puzzle mode, on the other hand, did a good job of balancing difficulty and atmosphere, which was one of my biggest complaints about the game before Puzzle Mode was a thing. While it is hard to really compare the atmospheres between the two modes (Original Lite, the first one I played and Puzzle Mode), I think if I had been able to play Puzzle Mode from the get-go that I would have had so much more intense of a playthrough rather than me just clicking through the menus hoping for the stars to align.

Don't get me wrong, though; there's still some trial and error here. Fortunately, due to the nature of Puzzle mode, you won't see right actions not work or wrong actions work fine due to RNG. It really does make the game a whole lot better. While some may argue that this detracts from some of the replay value, I really don't see this game as a game to be replayed a lot. Anyways, even with the predictable nature of Puzzle mode, the atmosphere of the game was still very well portrayed. Apart from that, though; that's really all I have left to say about this game. Puzzle mode really did save this game. It still may not be the most fun of games, but in Puzzle mode there's enough outs so that RNG doesn't actually screw you over while still retaining quite a bit of atmosphere that can be portrayed in Original when the stars align. 7/10.

Story: For the longest time I was worried that this would be one of those, It's all in your head" stories. Then I was worried that it was a Digital Devil Saga-esque thing. What's really going on... could honestly use a lot more explanation. The game makes constant references to Gods (hell
hoursPlayed: but you never really know if there are actual Gods or if it's just religious adulation. Everything else is pretty well explained

reviewText:
My entire team froze to death because I forgot to light a fire. 10/10.

The amount of negative reviews on here is ridiculous. This is a game that forces you to manage your time and manage it well; a mechanic that is just as refreshing as it is difficult. To fully enjoy this game you are going to have to put a few hours into it, something that the majority of these negative reviewers have not done.

Sure, the end product is completely different to what I expected. At first I hated what I was playing. It wasn't until I lost the first level for the millionth time that I realised just how rewarding it is to progress bit by bit until you manage to perfectly use the short supply of time that you have.

All in all this is a trial and error game and it is absurdly difficult, but it is rare to find a game these days that is truly as rewarding as it is difficult to master. You will lose, my god you will lose, but eventually you will win.

reviewText:
This isn't a laid-back adventure that some people are used to. It's a gritty survival game in the point n' click format. That said, it is a story-driven experience that gives context to the challenge, trial-and-error, consequences, and the prices you pay to reach your goals. It's all about managing your resources and paying attention to other people's morale and actions. The game actually lets you know how your decisions work, it just requires more of reading between the lines and paying attention to what's been said. The Original difficulty throws in chance, so I recommend Puzzle Mode to keep a consistent challenge.

The story of Sgt. Burden's mission to keep his teammates alive and face terrorist group Xenolifer is one that requires more thought. It's not accessible for anyone who wants a simple plot, let alone a straight-forward explanation to some of its, to avoid spoilers, more avant-garde direction with the narrative contextualizing the game mechanics of choices and consequences. I was close to accusing Gods Will Be Watching for a plot-hole or two, but finishing the game and letting the story marinate in my mind made it much more acceptable and logical.

Gods Will Be Watching is not intended to be a simple and light-hearted experience. I would go as far and say this is the point n' click equivalent of The Last Of Us, Dark Souls, and Metal Gear Solid 2, in terms of inaccessible but rewarding narratives.

reviewText:
A brutal, unflinching existentialist narrative hidden behind an awful game design misstep.

Gods was built in such a way that you can be clever and play perfectly and still lose most of the way through a scenario. And after a fairly engaging first level, the game slams this home on you in the second.

Punishing random chance is the bread and butter of Gods, even in the so-called narrative mode that's supposed to make for an accessible, easy-to-play story.

Think you're doing well? Have an instadeath that you can't respond to at the start of a scene, simply because the RNG doesn't like you.

Masocore games where you have to savescum your way to victory are fine, but at least they understand that it shouldn't take you twenty minutes every time you do it.

Do yourself a favor. If you're even remotely interested in Gods, youtube it. The concepts and the art and a lot of the mechanical design are really good, but actually playing the game is a miserable, nail-biting timesuck.

reviewText:
This game isn't for everyone for sure. It takes a point and click adventure and boils it down to its very essence and then introduced more failure (alternatively, say 'small adventure game with a heavy resource management component' either one should give you an idea). The mechanics are quite simple, but the game is tough as nails.

It's not perfect, and I can understand a lot of the complaints that people have, but I really loved playing this game, and I thought it had a hell of an ending. I streamed it, and so I felt a bit corny reading some of the dialogue, but that aside I found the story quite engaging. I also loved how the developer integrated the fact you're likely to behave in an 'unrealistic' (ie. overly risky) fashion into the story itself.

Don't try it if you won't enjoy something simple, and please don't cheat yourself out of the satisfaction of beating it on the classic mode. Provided you have the patience and interest in doing these two things, I give this game a strong recommendation, and find it well deserving of much more than the 'mixed' review it currently gets.

reviewText: This game is a brilliant subversive take on the adventure genre. reviewText:
Excellent game people mostly complain about for it's difficulty and put it in the tab of poor game designing. Resource management is always enjoyable.

Most arguments against the game I heard when it was fresh was the repetitiveness and how you can't skip the dialogues you are forced to re-read  (yes you can skip the dialogues).

Other complain I heard was considering chapter/mission 2 . So you are being tortured to get info out of you and one torture includes russian roulette. Argument I heard against the game and the scenario at that point was that it's based too much on luck and how that one situation can put you back the whole scenario. I count points for the game from that situation, it's excactly that kind of spychological pressure on the situation that made the gaming experience so very vivid.

The game is dark souls kind of challenging set in different kind of context, with nice story that get's a bit confused with itself at times ( curse of scrambled chronology plot design?). Overall it was 15 hours worth of fun for me ( Desert scenario aside, that is just frustration and tears). Money well spend on the collector's edition of the game.

reviewText:
This is not your average adventure game. Through out all of the missions there is an easier way of doing things and there is the morally right way of doing things. In simple terms if you have less people you dont need to spend extra resourses on them. What makes this game worth playing is the challenges that it has for the levels. It is relatively easy to play through the game on original difficulty and get through it, however, when you are trying to do the right thing is when it gets difficult and this is where the challenges come in.

The game is punishing and some times it does rely complete on chance, however, this is rare and it makes getting through the missions that much more satisfying, not only that the missions are short (20mins -30mins) so if you lose halfway through it's not a game killer.

This game is for anyone that likes to best tested. It requires you to want to make the right desicions but to sometimes be able to put winning the game above what is morally right.

reviewText:
A super tough and stylized game about making tough decisions for the good of the team. Everyone can die but you.

Pros:
•Very atmospheric and beautiful pixel art, a good example is the desert/canyon level.
•You go to a variety of places, doing a variety of tasks. No two levels are similar.
•Choices for easier difficulties, though discouraged. They even added a choice to remove all random elements, in response to complaints.
•When they say difficult decisions they mean it, they hold up on that part.
•Shows a neat little graph-like thing of all the decisions you made, and what percent of other players made those decisions.

Important Notes:
•The game does not save to the steam cloud; I played half the game when I stayed at my cousin's house for the week, and when I got home none of it was uploaded. This may have changed, if its important to you, look a little more into it.
•The game occasionally makes you take out a pen and a sheet of paper, which in my opinion made it a little more interesting, but some may not like that.
•The second level is a level about choosing how you receive torture. This level is one of the hardest, and truly affected me for about half an hour after each session of trying to beat it. Very dark stuff.

Cons:
•If a crew member dies in one mission, they magically reappear in the next. I understand why, but they could have come up with some stupid excuse other than just *BAM* he's back and was never gone.
•Can get somewhat tedious, often you get into a cycle of doing the same exact things.
•Crashed once for me, erased some of my progress.

6/10: For all that it is and however hard it tried, wasn't as gripping as some other games. It does supply what it advertises.

It's all about efficient time and resource management, with hazards and dangers thrown in to cause hiccups in your plans. reviewText:
Before posting my review, I would like to start out by saying I believe that this game should be played on Original Difficulty only, as it preserves the essence of the game which I will attempt to capture in the review.

This game really feels like this medium's 'great literature'.  It's not the most enjoyable experience out there in terms of gameplay, but it sure is a treat for the mind.  It somewhat reminds me of Lord of The Flies: I did not enjoy reading the actual book because the story infuriated me, however, I really appreciated the underlying themes and messages the book carries.  Gods Will be Watching is similar to LoTF in this aspect.

Players control Sgt. Burden as he tries to keep himself and his team alive through 7 (there's also a free DLC chapter) brutally difficult scenarios.  Players will try, fail, and try again only to fail once more due to the heavy reliance on the RNG.  One might then begin to wonder if their choices even mean anything - up to 40 minutes of work can be wiped out by a single event that's not even within their control.  It creates this very tense environment, knowing that one is doing their best, yet is still not in control of their own fate: that privilage belongs to the Gods, who are indeed watching you.

This raises an important question: 'why would anyone want to play a game where they aren't in full control of their destiny?', and, at least in my interpretation, is the point.  This game isn't about the gameplay, but the overall experience.  Once one accepts that failure is inevitable in this game, one can plan around it.  Each failure will come with a lesson, thus increasing the odds of success on subsequent runs.  Once players accept and embrace the nature of the RNG will the game truly shine because then they will have fully grasped everything the game has to offer.  Failure in this game should not be a maddening experience, nay, it should be an enlightening one, even when it occurs through no fault of the player.

(This paragraph section may contain some slight spoilers about the game's general theme and tone)

One might even wonder about the choices presented in the game, and of their significance; one might even begin to see the parallels drawn between the game and real life in this vast, possibly infinite, expanse of space we call home.  On a scale the size of the Universe, does anything anywhere even matter?

The entire game, from it's RNG elements, to its abundance of failure, to its minimalistic nature, to everything else, constitute a carefully woven lesson in Existential Nihilism, one that is retread and enforced in the game's finale, which brings every component and set peice together and wraps it up into a neat knot.  Every question posed by the game and even questions the player has about the game are brought to the fore and resolved in the finale - questions such as 'did my choices really matter?', 'why do I keep ending up wandering the desert when I fail?', and 'why are people who died in a previous chapter alive in the next?' are probably among the most important ones resolved.

In the face of such abundant failure, even the most difficult choices become mundane, almost routine, throughout the millions of attemts at becoming the legend that is Sgt. Burden.

The one (free) DLC chapter emphasises the game's main points: it takes the ending and adds on a meta-ending to it, which carries the same themes as the original ending, and builds upon them, thus driving the fateful point home once and for all with tremendous force.  One important thing to note however, and I really want to emphasize this, is that the nature of the gameplay, namely, the focus on the RNG and seeming absentness of impactful moral choices, were by design, a fact that will only become apparent upon completion of the game.  The resource management gameplay aspect is simply a medium through which the developers convey their story.

A friend recently mentioned to me that the game shares many parallels to the Myth of Sisyphus, and that given the situation presented in the DLC chapter, it seems to have served as inspiration or as a guiding foundation for this game.  I am definitely inclined to believe this is true, and its article on Wikipedia can explain Existential Nihilism/Absurdism much better than I can.

I highly, highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a difficult (puzzle) experience or some excellent food for thought.

Before I conclude, I would like to pose a question to the reader, one that is best saved for after  all 8 chapters of the game have been completed.  From the perspective of a person in the real world, was the player one of the Gods who were watching Burden, one who knew that his plight was futile, yet compelled him to carry one despite the fact, and put him through the meat grinder over and over until the outcome, however arbitrary (think back to when Liam broke the 4th wall), was satisfactory?  Powerful stuff, this game.  Powerful stuff.

reviewText:
Gods Will Be Watching. I love it.
It's one hell of a game and it's a bit frustrating with the difficulty but that's what makes it so fun!

(and just a quick note to the Not Recommended reviewers saying if someone dies they come back; The game is set in the far future, and you expect them to not make copies of the dead people? You also didn't read the dialouge then because if you do let them die or lose limbs, they talk about it later. (to avoid spoilers of names) The team's soldier said he enjoyed his mechanical arm but it kept the ladies away, if he lost it. The engineer responded that he was glad to help the Sarge even from the dead, if you allowed him to perish. Anyways..)

The game has a unique RNG-type way of running it making it different each time. Wincing in real life praying that it will cooperate with your choices when you're in a tight spot. Praying to the Gods that are watching. Planning ahead, it's much like the game of Chess with a similar mind set. You have to plan ahead from your past mistakes. No one needs to see more pixelated brains on the floor! Which brings me to the next thing. The artwork.

The whole game is just pixels. But the game is ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful, absolutely beautiful. Others might not agree but I think I speak for the majority when I say how amazing it is. And it's all just pixels. It's such a wonderful game. And the music.

The music is very simple. Not anything too complex, but then you realize after about an hour or an hour and a half. You've been listening to the same music, and it mends the frustration. The soundtrack is beautiful and simple, and even when played over and over, I bet nearly no one has gotten tired of it. It makes this great game even better.

The different chapters are well thought out, the artwork is beautiful, the music is amazing, everything about this game I can say is good. I would DEFINITELY recommend this game.

reviewText:
I played this game when it was still an indie prototype from a game jam.  And it kicked my ♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ing hard.  I was frustrated, but I was also intrigued.  Punishing gameplay can be intentional and can often bely a fascinating enigma of a game.  Just ask any Dead/Dark Souls fans.

I am writing this review to counter the many negative reviews I have seen of this game.  Anyone who has reviewed this game negatively has no ♥♥♥♥ing idea what they are talking about.  However, that is largely due to the fact that the game didn't start out with the multiple difficulties it has now.  Many reviewers played it when only the Original" difficulty existed when the game is infuriatingly difficult for all but the most hardcore (which I am most empathetically not).

I guess I was fortunate to not have time to get around to playing the game until the "Mercy Update" came out.  I had been following the game since I saw and played the game jam prototype.  In the prototype I barely made it 7 days without everything going to hell (The prototype was what became Chapter 4).  When I tried the commercial version on Original Light I was done before I was halfway to the Chapter 1 goal.  I had to play on Puzzle Mode Light.  LIGHT.  I am not an inexperienced gamer and I might have made it through on Puzzle Mode but considering how many times Chapter 5 kicked my ♥♥♥ I know I should not be so arrogant to think so.

Simply put
date: anyone who complains about the difficulty (ESPECIALLY after they added the other difficulties) has no ♥♥♥♥ing clue what they are talking about.\n\nTHE POINT of the game is the difficulty.  It is the base DNA that was present even in the nascent prototype.  The difficulty MUST be high.  The entire point of the game is moral ambiguity and hard decisions.  How can a game force you to feel these things if the difficulty is not cranked up?  How can a game force you to choose between running out of food (which would cause characters with low morale to commit suicide) and killing the least useful member of your troop so that the others would survive
recommended:
without making the "save everyone" option almost impossible?

But the Mercy Update fixes that.  Because the multitude of difficulties added makes this game accessible for players of all levels of masochism.  And that is a good thing.

Because the story is a masterpiece.  A complex tale of gray areas
hoursPlayed: branching pathways
voteText: personal discoveries
helpfulPercent: and hard choices.  The music is masterful in its creation of an atmosphere. The gameplay combines adventure game style branching pathways with the tense resource management of a thriller strategy game.  You will be surprised how tense this game will make you.\n\nBut most importantly
votesHelpful: at least to a player such as myself
votesTotal: this game fulfills my criteria for "Games As Art".\n\nMany games can be considered art
votesFunny: but for me
commentsCount: the true pinnacles of the media embrace message and metaphor in a way no other medium can: through gameplay.\n\nI can't say much else about it due to spoilers
column16: but the game embraces its branching pathways
column17: gray areas
column18: and hard moral choices into it's core story to create a metaphor about the hard choices we make through life.  When the gameplay and story intersect to become a metaphor unto themselves is when games truly become the sublime.\n\nThis game is EASILY one of the best games of 2014.  Many of us just needed the lower difficulties to see that.  Don't be so arrogant that you feel you can't play it on the lower difficulties.  The INTENT of the game is to be punishing and inspire HARD CHOICES.  It's fine if you can't handle that but if you dismiss this game out of frustration you are robbing yourself of one of the few experiences of a truly inspired piece of interactive software."

reviewText: The Metacritic score for this game is extremely misleading and may cause some users to miss out on what is perhaps the most visceral game I have played this year.\n\nLearning to appreciate Gods Will Be Watching means overcoming some barriers.  The first such barrier will inevitably be the graphics.  For someone such as myself who was raised on sprite based games this retro graphic style is part of the allure but I know for others (such as my child) the gut reaction is the graphics of that game suck!"  What you
date: the skeptical buyer needs to understand is that the graphics of this game are an aestetic and artistic choice.  Yes
recommended: this game could easily have been created utilizing modern 3d graphics and it probably would have still been fun.  The graphic style complements the entire game themetic:  do more with less.  The entire game you struggle to do as much as you can with extremely limited resources.  This theme can be read as the theme of the game in general
hoursPlayed: the game designers endeavoured to accomplish as much as they could with as little as possible.  We will return to this argument later.\n\nRelated to this first barrier is the second obstacle the player must overcome:  one of the most steep and unforgiving learning curves of any game I have played in perhaps a decade.  In a way this difficulty is appropriating the difficulty of older sprite based games before the invention of quicksaves and quickloads.  Not all of the complaints of the difficulty are without merit though.  I found the pacing of this difficulty somewhat random.  Instead of starting off difficult and ending up super difficult
voteText: near impossible levels are followed by relative walks-in-the-parks.  I think some better planning in this regard by the developers could have lead to a better recepection of the game.  That said
helpfulPercent: I think the difficulty  of the game
votesHelpful: like the sprite-based graphics is an artistic choice.   Ostensibly it is a love-letter to mind-blowingly difficult rogue-like games of yesteryear.  It is important to understand though that the difficulty of the game is supposed to be a mirror of the morally difficult situations you find yourself in in each level.  The threat of making a bad decision is made more visceral when you understand that you may be very close to having wasted nearly an hour of your time for nothing.\n\nIf
votesTotal: you are willing to perservere past these barriers
votesFunny: an extremely rich and rewarding experience awaits.  The game draws inspiration from such varied sources as Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs
commentsCount: the film Edge of Tomorrow
column16: The Dark Tower series
column17: as well as the entire encyclopedia of Science-Fiction tropes.  The two things this game does better than many others out there is tension and meta-gaming comentary.\n\nI'll try to keep this spoiler free but I must give kudos to the developers for showing how flat sprites can build tension.  In one level a torturer decides which device he is going to use that day.  His blocky sprite hands moves slowly from potential weapon to potential weapon and though you cannot really make out anything
column18: you can envision it.  Even the way he slowly takes a sprite based drag from his sprite based cigarette builds a whole much greater than its constituent parts.  Ultimately
column19: this game wags a shaming finger at AAA games who have access to million dollar CGI video and high end 3d graphics but who produce products empty and soul-less.\n\nAs I mentioned before this game seems to be speaking not only to its industry but to those who consume it.  The main characters name is "Burden" connoting not only his in-game responsibility but also how he functions as a work-horse for you
column20: the player.  The character of Burden slowly becomes aware that there is something awry in his decision making process and that problem is *you*
column21: the player.  The titular "watching gods" are not some fictional deities
column22: but you
column23: the player meddling and interferring in the gaming world.  The game asks the player to not be a detached meddling god but to invest in the characters emotionally.  The game provides a compelling world (via excellent sound
column25: and yes
column26: graphics) and asks you to simply try.\n\nAnd based upon the metacritic score
column27: many players seem unwilling to do so.  They would rather quickload up their quicksave and blow the heads off of people wearing turbans and then teabag them with special American flag boxers they purchased as a DLC.  The developers of this game have recognized a sort of illness in this industry and like Burden and his cohorts have attempted to make a remedy for it.  Ultimately
column28: the choice of whether to take that cure (and purchase this game) is yours.\n\nChoose wisely."

reviewText: Gods Will Be Watching is one of my top video game picks of 2014. It is a turn-based point-and-click moral puzzler" set against a futuristic sci-fi / bioterrorism setting. I just finished it (rare for me to actually finish a game these days)
date: clocking in at around 13 hours. It is great and you should play it and here's why.\n\nFirstly
recommended: what is this game about? It's hard to describe what genre it is in. UI-wise
hoursPlayed: it's a point-and-click puzzler
voteText: but it doesn't work like normal puzzle games. It's divided into six scenarios
helpfulPercent: and each has totally different mechanics. You give orders to your guys
votesHelpful: and each order typically takes some unit of time
votesTotal: so you have to prioritize which actions to take (although some scenarios let you do actions in parallel). Do you execute a hostage to keep the others in line? Do you free a hostage in exchange for more time? It essentially comes down to juggling a set of variables
votesFunny: and if any of them drops below a threshold
commentsCount: you die. There are always a couple of different valid approaches to each problem.\n\nFor example
column16: in the first scenario
column17: you take hostages while your team attempts to hack into a research station. You're barricaded in and the police are slowly marching in. You need to keep the hostages in line (calm so they don't make a run for it
column18: but not too calm that they try to take you down)
column19: negotiate to keep the police a safe distance away
column20: increase your hacking rate
column21: and keep your hacker from being locked out of the system. Fail to attend to any of these duties for too long
column22: and you're hosed.\n\nThis game is very hard. You'll often try each scenario a dozen or more times before you finally succeed. (It has easy mode settings
column23: but it begs you not to use them or you'll spoil the fun.) And that's the whole fun of it: experimenting with the various controls in each scenario and learning the mechanics by observing the results. After a few scenarios
column24: you'll have a general sense for how to be good at GWBW
column25: but you won't have a clue how to tackle the next scenario. There's also a strong luck component involved
column26: and this is important: you can't win just by memorizing a sequence of actions or by trial and error. You must understand the mechanics so well that you can maximize your probability of success. Once you've "cracked" a scenario
column27: you can beat the random number generator and can win it in 2 or 3 tries. (In this sense
column28: the game feels a bit like FTL.)\n\nThe 8-bit graphics are 8-bit style are drawn and animated nicely; the music is splendid. The story is epic and well worth following (though it is extremely complicated and involves reading huge walls of text). It also features extremely graphic violence
column29: as well as some bad gender stereotyping (the few women in the game are all "nurturing" type characters). The tough question for me is: is the game really about moral choices? On the one hand
column30: you can just treat each scenario as an optimization problem
column31: with each character being just a resource to be used up. But it's also hard not to feel an attachment to the characters and want to keep them all alive. The one critical flaw in the moral choices is that it doesn't matter who dies in a given scenario: they are always alive again at the start of the next one. That tends to devalue the characters' lives in each scenario. But I'll admit
column32: it would be pretty hard to design a story so dynamic when most characters can potentially die on most missions.\n\nGods Will Be Watching is
column34: a deeply mechanics-based game that rewards experimentation
column36: and understanding. You can play the original "survival" prototype here[www.deconstructeam.com]
column37: but be aware that this version is severely unpolished compared to the final game (the prototype scenario is in the final game and much improved). And remember... GODS WILL BE WATCHING!"

reviewText: This game was great.  Its simplicity of controls (the whole game is point and click) made a nice balance for the very serious storyline and moral choices.  The storyline itself is gripping..and while it's good from the beginning, it develops and gets better and better as you progress.  By the end, you will be left feeling satisfied, and as the credits roll you will be left to your own thoughts and emotions, how you felt about the characters and all the choices you made throughout playing.  I seriously recommend this game to anyone looking for an interesting, different game to play with a good storyline and heavy choices.  8/10

reviewText:
Okay, okay, I'll write a real review. Might be a bit haphazard since I just finished the game like 20 minutes ago and it's 2am, but whatever.

Let's get a few quick things out there first:

Mechanics are standard point-and-click, not much to say about it. The only method of control you have is your mouse. That's it. It's a point-and-click game.

Graphics are absolutely phenomenal, in my opinion. The art is gorgeous. I will admit the font used is difficult for me, PERSONALLY, to read, but others may not have a hard time with it like I did. I ended up getting used to it but it was still a bit of a pain and that's my only real complaint.

Now to the meatier stuff. Gods Will Be Watching is a relatively short game - I finished it in five hours, though I will admit I was on the easiest difficulty and therefore failed probably a hell of a lot less than I might've if I were playing on a harder difficulty. Point is, I got five hours out of it, which I felt was fulfilling. I didn't feel the game was lacking.

reviewText:
Excellent game people mostly complain about for it's difficulty and put it in the tab of poor game designing. Resource management is always enjoyable.

Most arguments against the game I heard when it was fresh was the repetitiveness and how you can't skip the dialogues you are forced to re-read  (yes you can skip the dialogues).

Other complain I heard was considering chapter/mission 2 . So you are being tortured to get info out of you and one torture includes russian roulette. Argument I heard against the game and the scenario at that point was that it's based too much on luck and how that one situation can put you back the whole scenario. I count points for the game from that situation, it's excactly that kind of spychological pressure on the situation that made the gaming experience so very vivid.

The game is dark souls kind of challenging set in different kind of context, with nice story that get's a bit confused with itself at times ( curse of scrambled chronology plot design?). Overall it was 15 hours worth of fun for me ( Desert scenario aside, that is just frustration and tears). Money well spend on the collector's edition of the game.

reviewText:
It isn't an adventure game which is why I can't recommend it. False advertising.
So you know what you are getting:
The idea is you are to balance several environmenal factors: calm hostages, hack computer, argue with guards (Shadow Over Camelot board game anyone?). Each turn you select which one to do and the other factors suffer. If any one of them fails, you fail. That's it.

My opinion:
Hard is very frustrating. Medium is just frustrating. Easy is silly simple and unfulfilling.
The idea is neat, but it doesn't work for me.

reviewText:
For those wondering why there are such mixed reviews.

Gods Will be Watching does something that, by this point, more developers should be striving for. It takes the concept of what a game should be, and throws it out the window. GWBW is thrilling, compelling and intense, with out live first person action. It is increadbly different and fresh. This, however, obvioulsy bothers some people. If you want to play just another game, this isnt the game for you. If you want a refreshing experince that will have you cringing at pixal violance and morally torn about pixal lives, buy it right now.

reviewText:
Only 5 Words to sum this up:

Real-Life Management Jobs in a Nutshell.

Think about it: Managing resourses and people for those who you care for [Stage 4], managing a situation that you would want to not go out of control [Stage 1], keeping secrets away and hidden from your competitors [Stage 2], Managing your team's to complete an impossible task in a short matter of time [Stage 3], and even correctly navigating through a vast area to reach home in time for that steak dinner [Stage 5].  If you're wanting to go into management (because almost nobody wants to take that job or something like that) and want to know how it feels to become one, then this is the game for you to learn how managers work in given tough situations.

I personally enjoyed it, for it made me understand what managers go through in real life.  And them workers say that their managers in their cubicle job (or whatever they work at) are always after them because they abuse them a lot...

reviewText:
This game hasn't been very well received, perhaps due to some failures in properly communicating the nature of the game prior to launch. People were expecting a very different kind of game and were thus disappointed when the finished game failed to meet their expectations. What initially might seem like a somewhat ordinary point-and-clicker is in reality a complex resource management simulation that could essentially be represented as an array of gauges steadily, or randomly, ticking away or being manipulated in some mystical way by you, the player.

Without a doubt this will be a huge turn-off for some, perhaps the majority of gamers. Being restricted to seven unforgiving, minimalist survival scenarios might not feel like something anyone in their right mind would enjoy. What I want to convey, though, is that there is a very unique charm to this game, very much unlike anything else out there. The pixel art is stellar. The music, ohh, the music is fantastic indeed. Perhaps most importantly, though, the hopeless atmosphere and the brutality of the story is what appeals to me the most. Having spent twenty minutes lying, begging and enduring pain in a torture chamber, clinging to dear life, the moment when your torturer pulls out a revolver, slides in a singular bullet and spins the cylinder is soul crushing. Every drop of the hammer makes your heart miss a beat because you actually have your all your previous progress through the level at stake. The fact that, in the original mode at least, there is that unforgiving element of pure chance somehow makes every decision have that much more weight.

Again, this is not for everyone. At this point, I'd suspect you'll already know if something like this is your cup of tea. Even if you're turned off by the randomness or the plain difficulty, I'd still dare recommend this game to most fans of adventure games. With recent patches the difficulty can be toned down, and while I don't suggest you do this if you can avoid it, there is now the possibility to experience the story with less frustration. If you're up for this kind of stuff definitely pick it up. If you're on the fence, I suggest waiting for a sale.

reviewText: First off, this game is not for everyone this point cannot be  more emphasized. This game is very difficult and should not be played by those who don't have the patience to replay a stage over and over and over again. The difficulty might be an unattractive part of the game to some but for me and others who love this game it is one of the best parts of this game. This game is about survival, beating the odds, buckling down, making it by the skin of your teeth and how difficult it is to do so. The difficulty beautifully ties itself with the harsh realities of survival as each stage presents itself as an extreme situation where sacrifices must be made and even then in most cases you will lose. But you keep fighting, because thats what it takes, because thats what this game is about, because if it were easy, it wouldn't be worth doing and for those who fight and persevere, they will see the true significance of the story and its themes. And those who quit at the face of failure and difficulty won't, because they don't deserve to, they didn't do what this game demands: to have the will to fight and survive no matter the cost. A powerful game that shows that success is a road paved by failure and the refusal to give up.
