reviewText: I really like the concept, I like the art style, I like the theme, but the problem is that the game is unbelievably dishonest in the challenges it proposes. It presents you with a risk management scenario and have you devise a plan to crack it. Then midway through it changes the rules just because, and you fail. Even though you fulfilled the original goals. Sometimes it makes narrative sense - even if it's infuriating gameplay wise - but later on the game doesn't even bother to keep the pretense. At one point you're tasked with researching an antidote in 24 hours or everyone dies. It consists of cracking a 3 digit code out of a possible 5, your scientists inform you, and managing a myriad resources to meet that deadline. You devise a plan to meet that deadline. You meet it. Then your scientists inform you they forgot to mention"

reviewText:
Gods must be Watching is an expanded version of the original browser game. You can try it here to see if you like the gameplay.

http://www.deconstructeam.com/games/gods-will-be-watching/

This version comes with a puzzle mode alongside the normal mode. I finished it on the easy version of normal mode where probabilty factors into whether or not your actions are successful. The game also comes with a puzzle mode for people who dont like the idea of probability causing actions to fail.

I thought it was fun and engaging but this is defintely niche title that is not suited to everyone.

reviewText: Huge fan of Devolver Digital and preordered Gods with high hopes. Let me get this out of the way, Gods Will Be Watching is a puzzle game that is mercilessly hard that will require many plays that make the game frustrating. It is a frustrating game! That being said, it's writing and atmosphere are absolutely fantastic but lack luster characters stopped me from being engaged. The biggest problem is its marketing, I didn't know that this was going to be a TRIAL and ERROR game. There's definitely some solid concepts here (A survival mission a cold planet and a mission about you and you're friend tortued) that make the game amazing but the fact that I have to play through them 3+ times for its trial and error gameplay just made it frustrating.

reviewText:
If your interest in this game is fueled by the misinformation that it's a Tell-Tale style narrative where your decisions significantly shape the story, please listen, this is not that game.. What it actually is is resource management, set in different survival scenarios. Survive 20 days of torture, survive being stranded on an alien world, etc.

That's where the 'sacrifice' and 'hard choices' stuff comes in. Some character may have to die so there's more food to go around. This may sound harrowing but since it doesn't effect the narrative at all it's hard to get worked up over.

I was initially disappointed but in the end I did enjoy it. I just want to make it clear to any wandering consumers out there what this game is and is not. Cheers

reviewText:
I was so very hopeful for this game. Let me preface this by saying the art is wonderful, the music is great, the story is dark and full of meaningful undertones, and the characters are lively and interesting despite never hearing a word from them.

NOW sadly the gameplay has nothing to do with actual choice. It's an absolute crapshoot to play the game as the developers intended it on original mode because the choices you make are almost entirely RNG based off of luck almost completely. Would it feel like an acomplishment if I were to complete the game on original mode? sure, but I have no desire to do so, and that would require the game not giving me a god damn aneurysm within the first two chapters. The game boils down to some sort of resource managing skills or making an attempt to gauge a character's state of being and give your best guess at how they would react to which choices you have. In the second chapter you're being tortured and you get to choose in between torture sessions whether you'd like a medkit, painkillers, or intel brought to you for the next torture session, which would be a really cool little bit IF IT DIDN'T REQUIRE 20 CYCLES OF THAT TO MOVE ON. Oh, and if you die on day 10 or so, you have to start completely over from, thus elongating your game time spent flicking through almost entirely identical dialogue instead of playing the game and actually furthering the story. Absolute trial and error, you're really just praying the odds are in your favor.
For example I played through the first chapter on original difficulty and every time I died (which was a lot of times) the game gave me the little rundown of my choices and told me I had a balanced approach. Managing hostages, an assault, and hack progress/security requires some balance and in finally achieving the balance, instead of being rewarded I'm greeted with another death thanks to some dumb luck, until my balanced approach worked, I'm guessing because the game pitied me.
In the games defense though it does have the cool bits where your decisions are shown at the end of each chapter and how they size up to every other player reacted to the situation and the decisions they made, which is ♥♥♥♥ing cool. Now don't get me wrong I love games that punish the player and have a harsh learning curve, Binding of Isaac, the Souls games, Rogue Legacy etc. but all of those games can be mastered. Skill can be developed to further progress your time to beat and so on. Where Gods Will Be Watching loses me is in the random chance and luck required in order to advance. Instead of allowing its players to progress in the story with penalties for the mistakes they made, which would truly change how the game is played and how the story unfolds (which would be extremely helpful considering a point and click game is centered so heavily on story), it restricts the player to ensuring each chapter ends with a very linear story progression (in my experience, keep in mind I haven't beaten it) that can only be achieved through frustrating luck and trial and error.

Sadly, I wouldn't recommend this game, but boy do I wish I could because it's fun to look at, the story is captivating and it has some good stuff going for it, all of which are ruined by chance serving as a gameplay factor.

reviewText:
Excellent game. Somehow fun and harrowing at the same time.

Gods Will Be Watching aims (I think) to put you in the position where you can make monstrous decisions, but not 'in a split second of panic' like Walking Dead did; it gives you all the time in the world to choose to do something necessary, but positively atrocious. This way you get to dwell on the ramifications. Also in contrast, this time to Papers Please, only the Gods are watching. How you complete the objective is irrelevant to the game, and there's no 'second booth' assessing your mistakes or concessions. It's quicker to inject a lethal dose of a virus into a human patient to find if the antidote works, and sacrifice your men in the desert to cover more ground, but if you're as immersed as I was this won't be an easy decision.

Other reviewers will criticise the mechanics. Other reviewers are missing the point. Most moral choices are down to chance at the end of the day.

Long and the short of it is; I went in as a total pacifist and within ten minutes I was rationalising the knee-capping of tied up hostages.

reviewText:
GWBW is a game of many faces. On the surface it's a meter-management strategy game with many randomized factors in play. The story is a sci-fi thriller about leadership, sacrifice and rebellion (among other things).

Beneath the surface, there's a meta-story which constantly (and with subtlety) critiques itself and many other clichés in popular entertainment. If you have played Undertale, you might be more familiar with the idea of a meta-story: the player him/herself plays an important role in the game story (effectively breaking the 4th wall).

If you haven't played Undertale or don't have an understanding of meta-stories, then I would not recommend this game.
The gameplay is equally engaging as it is frustrating, but that is the whole point. The game mechanics serve more as a tool for narrative than for fun.

If you want a challenging and very narrative-driven game, then this is the game for you. This game tells many strong messages without even mentioning them, and that's what makes this game truly unique.

In my opinion it's an innovative masterpiece, pushing the boundaries of narrative-driven game design.

reviewText:
Full disclosure - I pledged €8 on Indiegogo for a copy of Gods Will Be Watching.

Gods Will Be Watching is a game with a fantastic design aesthetic but a poor gameplay loop. Ultimately the game is a 'stress simulator', each 'level' is a crisis situation where you have a number of choices open to you, each relying on a variety of factors that are strained as you progress until either failure or a (most often Pyrrhic) victory.

Whilst there are a number of difficulty settings that alter how tricky the task will be, ultimately I found they felt like unengaging number-crunching exercises after a few failed attempts at each mission. You begin to game the system, rather than going on instinct. In one mission, it may work out better to kill a comrade in order to preserve supplies for the rest of the group, but instead of feeling like a weighty and meaningful decision, it instead feels like removing a resource-draining column on a spreadsheet. On top of this, the level of frustration rises when some of these scenarios take so long to complete and can often fall apart at the last moment. This leads to you trying the scenario again, often repeating most of what you did the previous time, with a few tweaks to your 'logic spreadsheet' in the hopes it works.

Whilst this game may seem entertaining to some, I think most will find it repetitive, awkward and frustrating. A fantastic artistic aesthetic with questionable design.

reviewText:
So you're coming in the evaluation messages to know if you'll like this little baby huh ?
First comes first, this game is very, VERY difficult on original gameplay. On the other hand, in the Narrative mode, you'll end it very fast, but that aint challenging at all.
The thing is, somehow, i raged because it was too hard, i had trouble passing the first level and i passed it because there was a glitch, the second one was kind of easy and then i got stuck in the third level for too long.
This game is a pain when it comes to challenge because it's so damn ridiculous to  handle all the people all the time at once !
This is all about gestion, you got a crew, you got a thing to do, you got to survive, no matter what.
And this part is tricky, because you can sacrifice others to move on, but it can also stop you in your next mission.
Its so hard because you always have to check everything and even by doing that, some actions will end up provoquing the things you try so damn hard to avoid. A stupid hostage that you have been talking to 3 times in a row so he calms down only that another one jumps on you.
But, theres a but, the game is magnificent in some ways.
First of all, its a MacPixel like graphism, without the scatology ideas, you're not here to play around, the story is serious and dont think you can just kill everybody because you feel like it, otherwise you'll just end up stuck.
The world of thisgame is very axed on the Science fiction, and i love this kind of game, it was really a nice game on that matter.
Finaly the  story will put you on the line to choose, between your humanity and freedom, and thats nice.
Dont forget to play the last mission once you finished the game to learn more, i think i enjoyed it even more than the first part of the game.

reviewText: Why? That is a word that will have to leave your vocabulary if you want to enjoy this game because it does a lot of things that frankly make no damn sense. For example, it takes an hour to gather firewood and then another hour to actually place the wood into the fire. Then it takes another hour to ligtht the fire by zapping it with a laser. If you don't do this before dark you die... Also, you will be forced to eat raw meat while gathered around a blazing campfire because you are only allowed to cook during the day. You have to spend large parts of the game trying to prevent people from killing themselves in dumb ways. This game reaches a Shadowgate level of absudity in some of the ways you can die. That said, it is actually kind of fun for someone looking for something a little different.

reviewText: Outstanding puzzle game, and this is coming from a non-puzzle game guy.  Other puzzle games have frustrated me easily in the past by requiring me to pick out several objects camouflaged in the background, add them to my inventory, and then rub them against each other in the most unintuitive ritual possible in order to progress.  This game has none of that.  There are very clear indicators of progress, success, and failure for each mission that are simultaneously very clear and very natural.  To cite one particularly gruesome example, on one mission my characters were holding hostages.  The mental state of the hostages was very apparent by their stance.  If they were relaxed, they would be sitting down on the ground flat on their butts, resting with their palms on the ground saying things like Hey look
date: they're distracted".  If they were scared they would curl up into a ball and rock themselves in a self-soothing manner while saying things like "I can't take it anymore
recommended: I need to get out of here..."  The puzzle was to keep them somewhere in between the two extremes
hoursPlayed: since if they got to relaxed they would attempt to overthrow you
voteText: and if they were too scared they would make suicidal attempts to escape.  There was never any point in the game where I said to myself "what do I do next?"
